question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Just take it! Especially if you're a prospective stat or otherwise quantitative major. You'll get exposed to so much, he's pretty generous with curving/grading, and honestly the most wholesome person you'll ever meet. The class is difficult, but it's still worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Collaboration is a must- work with other students in the course on the problem sets and when reviewing for the midterms, as multiple brains are better than one. Lectures are very challenging if you have a weaker statistical foundation; preview lecture notes if possible and seek out additional resources online before lectures to get the most out of the classes and to be able to engage fully. Review lecture notes after lectures every week, as it's very easy to get behind in this class.Don't be afraid to ask questions, and don't feel discouraged if others seem to "get" the content faster than you do, since MESS is highly competitive and has some of the smartest people at Duke. Would especially recommend taking this class if you're not a prospective stats major, as it might change your mind and get you interested.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course to anyone, regardless if they are interested in statistics or not, because of its applicability to any subject.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Banks' class is very challenging, but he and your peers will provide ample opportunities for support and learning. Class lectures are challenging and sometimes frustrating but always fun and engaging. Dr. Banks is extremely kind and cares about the well-being and performance of every student.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The first half of the course is very hard, but Professor Banks will guide you through the problem sets during office hours and the midterms aren't impossible. The second half of the course is more chill and you'll learn some interesting things in the projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The concepts learned in this class can be very difficult in the beginning, but make sure to ask any questions if you don't understand. Dr. Banks understands the difficulty of the class for freshmen and will be very happy that you are taking control over your own learning. The second half of the semester is more relaxed with mostly presentations. Don't worry too much about your grade and just be eager to learn new concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Banks is one of the most brilliant people I have ever met.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - Professor Banks will be a very important person to have a connection with if you want to pursue statistics. You may not learn the most about statistics in this class but it's a good introduction to college, and you learn a lot of interesting stuff.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an excellent course to take if you want to learn without having to worry about the pressure of grades. The first half of the class is challenging, and it becomes easier as the semester goes on.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
-Dr. Banks is great
-the course will definitely challenge you
-the people in the course are all great and interesting people too
-it was a very good course to expose you to what Duke has to offer

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to appreciate Statistics in a new lense. I didn't really consider all the new and intricate ways there are of modeling and I thought that was cool. I also enjoyed how broad the subjects of the course were. There were weeks where we went deep into complex mathematics and then weeks where we looked at networks of high school hook-up culture. In terms of more concrete things we learned it was 1. A significant step forward in the stats one learned in AP stats. 2. It was my first class where the HW assingments were substantially harder than the tests, It's important to collaborate with others on those. 3. Make sure to go to office hours.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Modeling: I learned how to model various real-life situations using statistical and other models.
2. Question information: I learned to question information that seems wrong or incomplete, even if the information came from published papers. Information often becomes outdated and cannot be utilized in current times.
3. Ask questions: I learned that in a college environment, it is very important to ask questions when something is not clear. I learned that many instructors are delighted that you asked for help instead of being confused by yourself.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to do presentations
2. Critical thinking
3. How to analyze

response_text: I learned how to approach learning mathematical concept I did not understand, what questions I could ask in class that were most relevant, and how to approach a statistical problem in the real-world.
